Submachine Guns Table.name: 冲锋枪表

Suppresive Fire.name: 压制火力
Suppresive Fire.description:
压制火力

Suppressive Fire turns a firearm or other rapid-firing weapon into @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.范围效果攻击]{范围效果攻击 }. It trades accuracy for a hail of ammo to keep the enemies’ heads down.

A weapon must be able to fire at least as rapidly as a revolver and can’t require reloading in between shots.

Suppressive Fire uses three times the usual number of bullets for its @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.射速]{射速 } and always incurs @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.后坐力]{后坐力 } regardless of the weapon’s original @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.射速]{射速 } (the @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-edges.激情四射]{激情四射 } Edge, bipods, and tripods negate @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.后坐力]{后坐力 } as usual).

To make the attack, the shooter places a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.范围效果攻击]{中型爆散盖板 } on the tabletop and makes a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.射击]{射击 } roll (a single @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.射击]{射击 } die regardless of @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.射速]{射速 }—RoF comes into Maximum Casualties, below.) Figure @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.射程]{射程 }、@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.照明]{照明 }、@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.后坐力]{后坐力 }, etc., as usual, to the center of the template.

Next compare the total to each target in the template and consider any modifiers that apply to each (@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.掩蔽与障碍]{掩蔽 }, the @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-edges.闪避]{闪避 } Edge, the @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-powers.偏斜]{偏斜 } power, etc.). Success means the target is @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.分神与脆弱]{分神 }, and a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性投骰]{优良 } means he’s actually hit (no bonus @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.伤害]{伤害 } is possible from Suppressive Fire).

Maximum Casualties： Every target under the template can be @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.分神与脆弱]{分神 }, but it can only cause @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.伤害]{伤害 } to a number of targets equal to the weapon’s @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.射速]{射速 }. The attacker chooses which targets are hit among his possible choices.

Example: Gabe fires a minigun at a group of rampaging insectoids. He places a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.范围效果攻击]{中型爆散盖板 } over five of them and rolls his @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.射击]{射击 } die and a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性投骰]{不羁骰 }. He has the @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-edges.激情四射]{激情四射 } Edge so he ignores @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.后坐力]{后坐力 } but still subtracts 2 from his total for Medium Range. He ends up with a 9 on his @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.射击]{射击 } roll.

Two of the insectoids were behind a large rock and get Medium @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.掩蔽与障碍]{掩蔽 }. That subtracts 4 from the total so that’s a single success—they’re @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.分神与脆弱]{分神 }.

Three of the targets were out in the open so they’re hit with a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性投骰]{优良 }. Gabe can hit up to five given his weapon’s @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.射速]{射速 }, so all three take @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.伤害]{伤害 }.

The @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.射速]{射速 } of 5 means each “shot” is 40 bullets, multiplied by three for Suppressive Fire. That’s 120 bullets, which is why miniguns come loaded with lots of ammo!

Surprise.name: 突袭
Surprise.description:
Surprise

Combat often starts before everyone involved is prepared. An ambush, a sudden double-cross, or a trap might all give one side in a fight an edge over the other.

When this happens, the ambushers are automatically on @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.待机]{待机 }. Deal them in as usual anyway in case one of them gets a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.行动卡 (先攻)]{鬼牌 }.

The victims of the attack make a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.察觉]{察觉 } roll (if they haven’t already, perhaps from ambushers sneaking up on them). Those who make it are dealt in as usual. Those who fail get no @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.行动卡 (先攻)]{行动卡 } and can’t act in the first round of combat.

Test.name: 考验
Test.description:
Test

The @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.援助]{援助 } option allows a character to help out her allies. Test is the opposite—it lets him make things more difficult for his foes! Tests include embarrassing an opponent, throwing sand in his eyes, staring him down with a steely gaze, or anything else a clever player can think of to rattle his enemy and put him off-balance.

To perform a Test, the player describes the action and works with the GM to determine the most appropriate skill to roll for it. Tests are resisted instinctively, so the “attacker’s” @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性]{技能投骰 } is opposed by the @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性]{属性 } it’s linked to. Tripping someone is an @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.运动]{运动 } roll versus @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性]{灵巧 } since that’s what @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.运动]{运动 } is linked to. @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.嘲弄]{嘲弄 } is linked to @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性]{聪慧 }, so verbally humiliating someone is resisted by that @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性]{属性 }. @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.格斗]{格斗 }, when used as a Test instead of an actual attack, isn’t compared to @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.角色]{格挡 }—it’s opposed by @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性]{灵巧 }.

If the attacker wins the opposed roll, he can choose to make his foe @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.分神与脆弱]{分神或脆弱 }. If he wins with a raise, the target is also @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.伤害效果]{动摇 } or there may be other subjective effects as the GM allows, such as a tripped foe being knocked prone.

Modifiers: The GM must determine which modifiers apply to a Test. @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.射击]{射击 }, for example, should include @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.射程]{射程 }、@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.掩蔽与障碍]{掩蔽 }、@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.照明]{照明 }、@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.后坐力]{后坐力 }, etc. A hero with a bonus to his @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.角色]{格挡 } does not add it to his @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性]{灵巧 } when challenged with a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.格斗]{格斗 } roll, however, because the defender resists with @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性]{灵巧 }—not his @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.角色]{格挡 }.

Take the details into consideration as well—using @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.嘲弄]{嘲弄 } to hit a rival’s ego where it hurts, for example, might be worth a +2 bonus to the attacker.

Repetition： Using the same or similar action repeatedly quickly grows less effective, so the GM should apply a steep penalty if a character’s Tests become repetitive (or disallow it entirely).

Additional Dice： If characters have addi­tional dice for a Test, such as when using a weapon with a high @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.射速]{射速 }, he may roll all the dice but takes only the highest as his Test total. He doesn’t get multiple results and he can’t spread them out to other targets.

The Drop.description:
The Drop

Sometimes an attacker is able to catch a foe off-guard and gets “The Drop” on him. The GM decides when this is in effect—usually it’s when the victim is bound or completely unaware of an attack. The Drop usually happens up close but the GM can also allow it in other situations as she sees fit (a sniper attacking an unaware and stationary target).

The Drop adds +4 to a character’s attack and @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.伤害]{伤害 } rolls against that target for one @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.动作]{动作 }.

Knockout Blow: If a character takes enough @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.伤害]{伤害 } to be @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.伤害效果]{动摇 } or worse from an attacker with The Drop on him, he must make a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性]{活力 } roll (at −2 if the attack was to the head) or be knocked unconscious.

KO’ed characters stay that way for about half an hour or until the GM decides it’s dramatically appropriate to wake up. Note that Knockout Blows come from any kind of @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.伤害]{伤害 }, not just blows to the head!
The Drop.name: 奇袭

Thirst.description:
Thirst

An average-sized human requires two quarts of water a day. This requirement is doubled in very dry conditions (such as the desert) or areas of heat and high humidity (the jungle) as the character perspires constantly and begins to dehydrate.

If enough water isn’t available, the hero begins to suffer from dehydration. A day after he can’t get enough water, he must make a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性]{活力 } @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性投骰]{投骰 } every eight hours (every four hours in a very hot or humid environment). Subtract 2 if he has less than half the water he needs in that period, and −4 if he has no water at all. Failure incurs a level of @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.疲乏]{疲乏 } and @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性投骰]{大失败 } means he’s @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.疲乏]{力竭 }.

See the @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.生存]{生存 } skill when a character wants to search for water from the local environment.

Recovery: Characters recover Fatigue levels normally after receiving sufficient water.

Death: An individual @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.疲乏]{无力化 } by thirst perishes after 2d6 hours.
Thirst.name: 干渴

Three-Round Burst.name: 三连发
Three-Round Burst.description:
Three-Round Burst

A few military weapons can fire three rounds in rapid succession with one pull of the trigger. If the weapon has this ability, its @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.射速]{射速 } is 1 in that mode but it fires three bullets at once and adds +1 to the @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.射击]{射击 } and @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.伤害]{伤害 } rolls.

Touch Attack.name: 接触攻击
Touch Attack.description:
Touch Attack

A character who simply wants to touch a foe (usually to deliver a magical effect of some kind) may add +2 to his @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.格斗]{格斗 } roll.

Trait Rolls.name: 特性投骰
Trait Rolls.description:
Trait Rolls

To make a skill or attribute “check” or “roll,” simply roll the die assigned to it. If the result is a 4 or better (the “Target Number” or TN), the action is successful. For example, if a character’s @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性]{力量 } is a d6, he rolls a six-sided die. On a 4 or better, he’s successful.

Modifiers: Circumstances modify the die roll, such as shooting at something far away or finding a well-hidden clue. Some things, such as @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.射程]{远程攻击 }, have standard modifiers. It’s up to the GM to determine any modifiers for more subjective tasks, such as spotting an ambush or eavesdropping on a conversation through a door.

In general, an easy task, such as finding tracks in the mud, is made at +2. A difficult task, such as finding tracks by torchlight, is made at −2. A very difficult task, such as finding tracks in a rainstorm, is made at −4.

Multiple Dice: When a character rolls multiple dice, such as when firing a machine-gun, check each die separately.

The Wild Die

@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.不羁角色与龙套们]{龙套 } roll a single die when making a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性]{特性 } roll. @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.不羁角色与龙套们]{不羁角色 } roll an extra d6 and take the highest of their @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性]{特性 } die or the “Wild Die.” Both of these dice can Ace (see below).

One Wild Die Per Action: When @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.不羁角色与龙套们]{不羁角色 } roll multiple dice for a single action, such as when firing a machine gun, they roll only one Wild Die.

The Wild Die may replace a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性]{特性 } die or be ignored—it never adds another action or attack to the roll.

Example： Gabe has the Frenzy Edge (page 42). He rolls an extra Fighting die when making a melee attack along with a Wild Die. Only two of his dice can cause hits since the Wild Die can only replace a die, not add another attack.

Aces

All @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性]{特性 } and damage rolls in Savage Worlds are open-ended. That means that when you roll the highest number possible on a die (a 6 on a d6, an 8 on a d8, and so on), you get to roll that die again and add it to the total. This is called an “Ace.” Any modifiers to the die roll should be tacked on after adding up an Aced roll.

Example: Red attempts to leap a dangerous ice chasm. She’s a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.不羁角色与龙套们]{不羁角色 } with a d8 in @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.运动]{运动 }, so she rolls a d8 and a d6 and takes the highest result. In this case, both dice Ace (8 on the d8 and 6 on the d6). She rolls the d8 again and gets a 4 for a total of 12. She rolls the d6 again and gets another 6, followed by a 2—that’s a total of 14. Red leaps the chasm with ease…this time!

Raises

Sometimes it’s important to know just how successful a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性]{特性 } roll was. Every 4 points over the Target Number is called a “raise.” If your hero needs a 4 to shoot an opponent and rolls an 11, he hits with one raise (and would have two raises with a roll of 12). Figure raises after adjusting for any modifiers.

A single raise always provides an additional effect of some sort, such as bonus damage when attacking or a benefit determined by the GM for other rolls.

Opposed Rolls

Sometimes rolls are “opposed” by an opponent. The attacker gets a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性]{特性 } total, then the defender attempts to beat it.

The exact skills or attributes used in a contest are specified in each circumstance, or the GM can decide what makes the most sense. If two characters try to pull something from each other’s hands, for example, they make opposed @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性]{力量 } rolls. Sneaking up on someone is a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.潜行]{潜行 } roll opposed by @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.察觉]{察觉 } (which is detailed in the @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.潜行]{潜行 } skill description).

The acting character in an opposed roll always gets his @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性]{特性 } total first (including spending any @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.助力点]{助力点 }), and must get at least a basic success (TN 4) or he fails. The defender rolls next and must meet or exceed the first character’s result or the attacker wins.

The winner also uses his opponent’s total for purposes of determining raise effects.

Critical Failures

A Critical Failure occurs when a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.不羁角色与龙套们]{不羁角色 } rolls a 1 on both the skill die and Wild Die of a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性]{特性 } roll. The attempt automatically fails and something bad happens—a weapon is dropped or gets stuck, the attack hits a friend, the vehicle crashes, spells misfire (see @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.启动]{反冲 }), and so on.

Critical Failures cannot be rerolled, even with @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.助力点]{助力点 }.

Extras and Critical Failures： If an @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.不羁角色与龙套们]{龙套 } rolls a 1 on a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性]{特性 } check and it’s important to know if it’s a Critical Failure, such as when casting a spell, roll a d6. On a 1, it’s a Critical Failure. Otherwise it’s just a normal failure.

Multiple Dice： Some abilities allow char­acters to roll multiple @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性]{特性 } dice, such as the @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-edges.连击]{连击 } Edge or firing a weapon with a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.射速]{射速 } higher than 1. A Critical Failure with multiple dice occurs when more than half the die results are a natural 1. If the character is a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.不羁角色与龙套们]{不羁角色 }, the Wild Die must be a 1 as well.

Example: Gabe fires the auto-cannon of a high-tech hovercraft. It has a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.射速]{射速 } of 3 so he rolls three @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.射击]{射击 } dice and one Wild Die. If three or more of the dice come up 1s, including the Wild Die, it’s a Critical Failure.

Unskilled Attempts

If a character doesn’t have a skill for an action he’s attempting, he rolls a d4 for his skill die (and a Wild Die if a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.不羁角色与龙套们]{不羁角色 }) and subtracts 2 from the total.

The GM may decide certain tasks cannot be attempted unskilled, such as performing complex surgery or flying a commercial jet.

Reroll

Some @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.专长]{专长 } or abilities allow a character to reroll @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性]{特性 } (as long as they’re not a Critical Failure). To do so, roll all the dice again and get a new total. You may keep any of the totals generated, so rerolls never make things worse unless you roll a Critical Failure. This ends all rerolls immediately and becomes the result of the attempt—that’s the risk one takes in pushing the limits!

Multiple rerolls are allowed from different @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.专长]{专长 }、@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.助力点]{助力点 }, or other abilities.

Group Rolls

When you want to make a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性]{特性 } roll for a group of @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.不羁角色与龙套们]{龙套 } with like Traits, roll one Trait die as usual along with a Wild Die and treat this as the group’s result. This gives a decent average without making rolls for every individual.

Example: A group of soldiers attempts to slip through Gabe’s sensors. The GM rolls their @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.潜行]{潜行 } die (a d6) and a Wild Die and takes the best of the two as the soldiers’ total.

Traits.name: 特性
Traits.description:
特性

角色因其“特性”而得以成型，属性和技能根据骰子类型划分高低，d6属于平均水平，在此之上的骰子类型则代表能力更为优秀。

属性主要是用于抵抗诸如恐惧或超自然攻击这类效果的被动或内生能力.技能用于主动行事或是影响他人。

尽管偶有例外，但上述两个概念之间在根本上有所区别。

属性

属性不会直接影响技能投骰。《狂野世界》把学到的知识和训练所得视作最为重要且直接的要素。高属性能让人物得以更快地提升技能，解锁更多可选专长，后者能让两名具备相同技能的角色各有千秋。

所有角色初始时以下五个属性各自都是d4。

灵巧(灵巧)：衡量角色的灵活性，敏捷程度以及整体协调。

聪慧(聪慧)：衡量角色的先天智力，心智灵活程度以及脑子转得有多快，常用于抵抗特定类别的心智和社交攻击。

心魂(心魂)：自信、决心以及意志力，这常用于抵抗社交、超自然攻击以及恐惧。

力量(Strength)：身体力量以及健壮程度，同时这也是人物在近身战斗中的伤害基准，以及用来决定穿戴与携带东西的多寡。

活力(Vigor)：代表角色对于疾病、毒药以及毒素的忍受力和抗性，以及在倒下前能承受多少物理伤害，这通常用于抵抗疲乏效果，同时也是衍生数据中坚韧的基准。

使用属性

属性用于：

  • 在 @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.升级]{升级 }时决定技能的提升速度。
  • 解锁@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.专长]{专长 }限制。
  • 得出诸如坚韧或是近战伤害等@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.角色]{衍生数据 }。
  • 抵抗效果(诸如遭到@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.擒抱]{擒抱 }、反制法术、@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.奇术]{奇术 }或是@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.嘲弄]{嘲弄 }或@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.威吓]{威吓 }这类社交攻击)。

技能

人物在角色创建时有12点可用于购置技能的点数。小于关联属性(在技能名称旁边以括号标出)的技能提升起来比大于等于关键属性的技能更为便宜。参照@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.角色创建概要]{角色创建 }以及@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.升级]{升级 }。

核心技能会以红星标记，@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性投骰]{玩家角色 }的这些技能初始都是d4。

角色可以尝试自身并不具备的技能，但这会难上加难，见 @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性投骰]{未受训尝试 }。

该版本狂野世界的技能变化

以下是该版本《狂野世界》中最为重要的技能变化总结。

核心技能

每名角色以下五个基础技能初始都是d4：运动、通用知识、察觉、交涉以及潜行。d4并不意味着其擅长这些技能，只是在此之上有一点基础经验而已。

主要变化：

  • 从游戏中移除魅力。
  • 攀爬合并进@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.运动]{运动 }当中。
  • @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.通用知识]{通用知识 }现在由聪慧投骰变成单独的技能。
  • 探查现在更名为@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.调查]{调查 }以让其意思和用途更加清晰。
  • @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.集中]{集中 }成为@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.奥法背景 (异禀)]{奥法背景 (异禀) }的新技能。
  • 知识在大多数设定里被分拆成各个技能，尤其是@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.人文]{人文 }、@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.作战]{作战 }、@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.电子学]{电子学 }、@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.骇客]{骇客 }、@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.语言]{语言 }、@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.神秘学]{神秘学 }以及@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.科学]{科学 }。
  • 开锁现在是@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.贼活]{贼活 }技能的一部分，后者同样能处理扒窃、巧手、开保险箱及其他盗贼技艺。
  • @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.表演]{表演 }现在是新技能。
  • @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.修理]{修理 }及其用途定义得更为明晰。
  • 市井门道现在归入@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.专长]{专长 }。
  • 游泳由@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.运动]{运动 }处理。
  • 投掷囊括在了@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.运动]{运动 }之中。
  • 追踪纳入@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.生存]{生存 }之中。

创造其他技能

GM能创造自己想要或是设定需要的任何技能。若技能对用途有所定义，则应该致力于明确其如何运作。举例而言，如果你的星际冒险战役内星际航行占了一大部分，同时你认为使用航天系统不在电子学技能的范围内，那么你也许会新增一项航天学。

玩家同样能在得到GM许可的前提下新增自己的特色技能。然而，除非玩家主动找方法加以运用，否则这在大部分设定中可能都无法经常亮相。

例子： Deadlands: Hell on Earth里，角色必须要团结整个镇子以对抗正在接近的变种群落。艾米莉有一个自己创造的技能：新闻学。她决定通过该技能去写一篇动人的文章并将其印刷出来给镇子里的每个人阅读。她获得了优良，因而GM决定让整个镇子都团结在守护者一侧。

技能理念

新玩家有时会更重视诸如@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.格斗]{格斗 }或@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.射击]{射击 }这些较为宽泛的技能，同时尝试让其他所有技能也是如此。但技能系统的初衷是创造并体现角色本身。无论是狙击手或是弓兵，射手在许多设定里面都稀松平常，而且全都使用同一个能力—􍄔精确地用武器射击。在塑造这些角色时不需要同时给火器和弓矢各留一个技能。

然而，调查型角色的确需要许多不同的技能，因为他们处事方式各有不同。强硬的侦探在街头打听时需要@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.威吓]{威吓 }；社交名流混迹于上流社会；书虫则会钻入图书馆内；而计算机极客会使用@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.骇客]{骇客 }去取得想要的东西。

同时，一些技能合并起来并不合理。举例而言，@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.驾船]{驾船 }、@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.驾驶]{驾驶 }和@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.航空]{航空 }可以合并成“载具”技能，但当代不是每个会开车的人都能开飞机。这点在调整战役中的技能时要有所考虑。


综合调整值

先前版本的《狂野世界》里为诸如@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.潜行]{潜行 }和追踪(现已整合进@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.生存]{生存 })列出了一大票调整值。在该版本里，为了让GM能以更主观的立场放眼全局，着眼于那些无法统合在表格里的东西，我们移除了这些表格，让GM自己分配加值和减值，这通常在-4到+4之间。

这能让GM更综合地考虑所有因素，尤其是有所重复的部分(比如都影响视野的雨水和黑暗就不该叠加)，并简单快速地进行加总，而不用在紧要关头中跑去翻查表格。



熟悉度

如果通过展示角色不熟悉某一技能的特定用法能达到恰如其分的戏剧效果(诸如捡起一把外星武器并尝试通过@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.射击]{射击 }以其进行攻击)，那么GM就应该在总值上应用减值(通常是-2到-4)。

这样做时的减值大小完全取决于状况而定。举例而言，枪手在使用弓箭时可能会遭受减值，至少直到其花上一两天进行练习为止。如果玩家特别声明其教授角色是世界闻名的化学家，那么在GM要求他进行与古生代地理学相关的检定时，其@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.科学]{科学 }投骰可能会-4。(尽管如此，若是玩家能扮演出知识匮乏，这也是奖励助力点的好时机！

反复使用下的减值持续时间则取决于实际技能。物理上的减值在经过1天或之类的练习后可能就会消失，而基于知识的技能则减值只有在角色能获取合适资料且花时间研究对应主题后才会消失，举例而言，尽管角色主修法国文学，但倘若有时间学习莎士比亚，那就不应在@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.人文]{人文 }上遭受减值。

总而言之，熟悉度减值应该用于戏剧性效果，或是展示文化或科技水平的差别。即使如此，也应该保持故事流畅推进，不要纠结于细枝末节。

Trappings.name: 特效
Trappings.description:
Trappings

Trappings allow the core @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.奇术]{奇术 } presented in this chapter to have many different appearances. They usually have no game effect on their own, but are important for atmosphere and theme.

One character might fire a swarm of bees to attack her foes, for example, while another shoots red lasers from her eyes. Both are examples of the @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-powers.矢箭]{矢箭 } power and share the same mechanics, but they look and are described differently.

Trappings do matter when an obstacle or opponent has a particular strength or weakness. If an ice troll suffers +4 damage from fire- or heat-based attacks, for example, a blast a player describes as a fireball counts as a fire attack and does +4 damage.

Once described, a power’s Trappings don’t change without the @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-edges.奇才]{奇才 } Edge, or an @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.升级]{升级 }—see below.

A character can alter the power’s effects as she wishes using the @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.奇术调整]{奇术调整 }.

Synergy

Sometimes logic dictates a power’s Trapping should have some additional effect. Zapping someone with a lightning bolt while they’re standing in water should cause additional @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.伤害]{伤害 }, for example, or less if they’re wearing a rubber hazmat suit.

When this occurs, the GM can decide there’s synergy that either increases or decreases the effect or damage (GM’s call) by +2 or −2.

Oppositional forces, such as fire and ice or light and darkness, don’t have synergy against one another (though such effects are sometimes accounted for in some creatures’ @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.怪物图鉴]{特殊能力 }). If a fire @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-powers.爆发]{爆发 } hits ice armor (@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-powers.防护]{防护 }), for example, there’s no synergy because they cancel each other out.

Limitations

Sometimes a power’s Trapping imposes a limitation on the power. This gives the power focus at the expense of versatility, reducing the strain it causes the caster.

The Limitation is permanent and always in effect unless changed with an @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.升级]{升级 } as noted below.

Each limitation placed upon the power reduces its total @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.奥法背景]{奇术点 } cost by one (to a minimum of 1). If this would reduce the cost to 0, you gain a +1 bonus (+2 maximum) to the arcane skill total instead.

  • @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.射程]{射程 }: The power’s @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.射程]{射程 } is reduced to Touch (and its listed @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.射程]{射程 } is greater).
  • PERSONAL: The power's @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.射程]{射程 } becomes Self (and has a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.射程]{射程 } of Touch or the @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.射程]{射程 } Limitation above).
  • ASPECT: The character can only access one aspect of a power (that has more than one choice), such as @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-powers.滞缓/加速]{滞缓/加速 } or @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-powers.提升/降低特性]{提升/降低特性 }.

Adding & Changing Trappings

A character gets two new @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.奇术]{奇术 } when he takes the @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-edges.新奇术]{新奇术 } Edge. He may instead add Trappings to his @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.奇术]{奇术 } in place of one or two of the new @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.奇术]{奇术 }. A hero who takes the @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-edges.新奇术]{新奇术 } Edge, for example, could choose one new power and add an ice Trapping to her @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-powers.矢箭]{矢箭 }.

The GM may also allow a player to change the trapping of existing power when she gains an @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.升级]{升级 }. This should reflect a major change in the character in some way as determined by the player and GM.

More on Trappings

Trappings allow an endless variety of @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.奇术]{奇术 } and the sources of those @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.奇术]{奇术 }. Sometimes that might produce some st@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.射程]{射程 } results, so the player and GM must use common sense to figure out any inconsistencies. Here’s an example.

Gabe is an alchemist in a fantasy game. He decides his blast power manifests as a bag of small, explosive pots he hurls like grenades.

@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-powers.爆发]{爆发 } has a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.射程]{射程 } of @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性]{聪慧 } ×2. With a d8 @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性]{聪慧 }, that’s 16″ with no @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.射程]{射程 } penalties. This is sometimes better than using Athletics to throw an actual grenade, which has @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.射程]{射程 } penalties at 10″ and 20.” That’s okay—Gabe’s player has to track and use @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.奥法背景]{获得奇术点 }. Another character with traditional grenades doesn’t, but must contend with @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.射程]{射程 } modifiers.

Travel.name: 旅行
Travel.description:
Travel

Many epic tales feature trips across great expanses. Adventurers might endure a long voyage across the endless seas of 50 Fathoms or ride the dusty trails of Deadlands: The Weird West.

Below are some guidelines to help you figure out how long these journeys take and what dramatic events might happen along the way.

When to Use These 规则： If it doesn’t matter how long the trip takes, skip all this. Narrate the journey, maybe do an @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.幕间]{幕间 }, and get to the next scene. If you need to know how long the trip takes, or want to insert an obstacle or encounter of some sort, use the information below as a guideline.

The Basics： The mode of travel determines how many miles the group makes per day.

Travel Times

The rates below assume reasonable terrain and weather. Difficult conditions can drastically decrease progress (or increase it in the case of sailing with strong winds).

Average Travel Times
Transport Miles/8 Hour Day
Foot 24
Horse 30
Early Car 200
Modern Car 400
Sailing Ship* 30
Steam Ship* 40
Modern Passenger Train 400
Prop Plane 1,000
Commerical Jet 4,000

*Sailing ships (and steam ships to a lesser degree) are greatly affected by currents and winds. Strong winds or currents in the right direction allow them to travel about 60 miles per day. Poor winds or going against the current reduces them to 20 miles per day or less.

Encounters

If an area is dangerous or lawless, draw a card from the @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.行动卡 (先攻)]{行动卡 } once per day (or even two or three times a day in particularly dangerous areas). A face card or higher represents an encounter, and the card suit can be used to determine the type.

Draw twice more if the card is a Joker and combine the results—such as Enemies and an Obstacle or Strangers and Treasure (defined below).

Game Masters are highly encouraged to customize encounters based on their setting.

  • SPADES—ENEMIES: Monsters, enemies, or hostile beasts bar the way. Perhaps they lie in ambush if it’s a popular path, waiting for the next band of unwary travelers.
  • HEARTS—STRANGERS: The group comes upon neutral or friendly nonplayer charac­ters such as merchants, lost travelers, a guide, or even other adventurers.
  • DIAMONDS—TREASURE: Somewhere along the way is something of value—the hulk of a crashed ship with some remaining supplies waiting to be scavenged, a cache of useful or valuable minerals, or a magic item for sale or guarded by someone or something.
  • CLUBS—OBSTACLE: The heroes encounter an obstacle of some kind and must figure out how to circumvent it. Some examples are a flooded river, minefields, a decaying rope bridge, whirlpool, etc. The obstacle might also be defended by creatures or enemies as well.

Example: Irradiated Wastes

Red and Gabe are wasteland warriors in Deadlands: Hell on Earth, traversing an area outside of Las Vegas, Nevada, that’s been blasted by nuclear “ghost rock” bombs.

The GM draws a Jack of Clubs and decides the area is now a maze of jagged “glass chasms” and toxic sinkholes. This slows progress to a crawl for two days and makes them both roll for @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.疲乏]{疲乏 } from heat and radiation (see the @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.危难]{危难 } section).

The GM draws again later that day and gets a Queen of Spades. From one of the sinkholes slithers a swarm of irradiated serpents, hungry for fresh prey.

Two Hands.name: 双手
Two Hands.description:
Two Hands

A two-handed weapon can be used with one hand at a −4 penalty. He counts his full @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性]{力量 } for @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.伤害]{伤害 } but loses all other advantages such as @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.触及]{触及 }或@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.角色]{格挡 } bonuses.

Two Weapons.name: 双武器
Two Weapons.description:
Two Weapons

A character armed with two melee weapons adds +1 to his @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.格斗]{格斗 } rolls if his foe has a single weapon or is @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.手无寸铁]{无武装 }, and has no shield. It adds no bonus against creatures with @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.天生武器]{天生武器 }.

Wielding two firearms offers no special advantage other than additional ammunition.

Characters who want to specialize further can take the @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-edges.左右连环]{左右连环 } or @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-edges.双枪小子]{双枪小子 } Edge.

Unarmed Defender.name: 手无寸铁
Unarmed Defender.description:
Unarmed Defender

It’s difficult to @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.角色]{格挡 } a blade with one’s bare hands. An attacker armed with a melee weapon adds +2 to his @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.格斗]{格斗 } attacks if his foe has no weapon or shield. (This doesn’t stack with @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.奇袭]{奇袭 }.)

Unarmored Hero.name: 无甲勇士
Unarmored Hero.description:
Unarmored Hero

Pulp action tales often feature heroes with little or no armor defeating far more heavily armored adversaries.

In these settings, if a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.不羁角色与龙套们]{不羁角色 } chooses not to wear any @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.护甲]{护甲 } (ignoring shields), he adds +2 bonus to his @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.化解投骰]{化解投骰 }!

Unstable Platform.name: 不稳平台
Unstable Platform.description:
Unstable Platform

A character attempting to @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.射击]{火焰 }或@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.运动]{投掷 } a ranged weapon from the back of a horse or other mount, a moving vehicle, or other “unstable platform” subtracts 2 from his total.

Vehicle Notes.name: 载具注释
Vehicle Notes.description:
Vehicles

In the Vehicle Tables section are a number of sample vehicles for @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.地面载具]{陆行 }、@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.飞行器表]{飞行 }和@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.船只表]{水行 }, including some military vehicles such as tanks and armored personnel carriers.

  • SIZE: The Size and Scale of the vehicle relative to a human (see @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.体型与尺寸]{体型与尺寸 } and the @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.体型表]{体型表 } ). Vehicles can normally take three @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.伤害效果]{损伤 } before they’re @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.追逐与载具]{毁坏 }, but Large Vehicles can take one additional Wound, Huge vehicles two, and Gargantuan three.
  • Handling: The vehicle’s respons­ive­ness and maneuverability is added or subtracted from all its operator’s maneuvering rolls (@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.驾船]{驾船 }、@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.驾驶]{驾驶 }或是@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.航空]{航空 }). This typically ranges from −4 for particularly slow or sluggish vehicles to +4 for those that can turn on a dime.
  • TOP SPEED: Top Speed is expressed in miles per hour (MPH) rather than @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.移动]{移速 }  so it’s easier for you to look up real-world vehicles and use them in your game. The Chase rules only care about the relative speeds of vehicles anyway, not their actual speeds (see @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.追逐与载具]{追逐 })

    To convert miles per hour to @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.移动]{移速 }, multiply MPH by 1.5. See the @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.追逐与载具]{Vehicles on the Tabletop sidebar } to integrate vehicles into tabletop combats with characters.

  • TOUGHNESS: The vehicle’s base durability including @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.护甲]{护甲 } (in parentheses). Use the included vehicles as a guide (see @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.地面载具]{地面载具 }、@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.船只表]{船只 }和@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.飞行器表]{飞行器 }) when creating your own or writing up those that aren’t listed here.

    To estimate the @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.护甲]{护甲 } value of real world vehicles with Heavy Armor (tanks), start with +4 as a base, then add +2 for every inch of armor up to 10″, +1 per inch up to 20″, and finally +1 for every two full inches after that. A tank with 23″ of armor, for example, has an Armor value of (4+20+10+1)=35.

    Adjust to reflect any other factors such as modern composite materials and the like.

  • PASSENGERS: The number of crew plus any additional passengers it can transport. A notation of “2+8,” for example, means it requires a crew of two and can carry up to eight additional passengers.
  • COST: The average price of the vehicle.

Vehicle Notes

Air Bags & Safety Harnesses: Passengers with vehicular protective devices take half damage from collisions (round down). See @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.追逐与载具]{毁坏 }.

Amphibious： The vehicle can enter water without flooding or capsizing. See the individual descriptions for their movement rates while in water.

Anti-Missile Counter Measures (AMCM)： AMCM systems are electronic jammers, chaff, and flares. They add +2 to a user’s maneuvering rolls to evade missiles (see @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.导弹表]{导弹 }).

Four-Wheel Drive (4WD)： Treat each inch of @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.移动]{困难地形 } as 1.5″ instead of 2″.

Heavy Armor： Only weapons marked as @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.重武器 (HW)]{重武器 } can hurt this vehicle, regard­less of the damage roll. This keeps a lucky pistol shot from destroying a tank. Vehicles with Heavy Armor halve damage they take from colliding with other obstacles (including vehicles) that don’t have Heavy Armor.

Unless otherwise specified, these vehicles have less protection on their sides and rear. Attacks that hit either (GM’s call) increase the weapon’s damage dice by one, thus 3d8 becomes 4d8, for example.

Hover： The vehicle is a hovercraft and can ignore most low terrain obstacles and water.

Infrared Night Vision： Thermal imaging devices halve @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.照明]{照明 } penalties versus targets that give off heat.

Converting from
previous editions

Vehicles in this list have slightly different statistics from previous editions：

Acceleration (“Acc”): Acceleration is now factored into Handling and Top Speed.

Climb: Climb has now been factored into each aircraft’s Handling value.

Pace： @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.移动]{移速 } in previous editions was based on “tabletop” speed and much lower than the values in this edition. To convert a real vehicle, look up its actual top speed in MPH. For fictional vehicles, mul­tiply the old Top Speed by 3 to get its Top Speed in real world MPH.

Linked: Weapons of the same type may be dual or quad linked and fired as one (triple linked is ineffective). Dual linked weapons add +1 to hit and +2 damage; quad linked weapons add +2 to hit and +4 damage.

Example： A pilot with d8 @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.射击]{射击 } in a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.飞行器表]{喷火MK2A战斗机 } (8× machine-guns, @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.射速]{射速 } 3) rolls 3d8 for each wing, adding +2 to his Shooting total and +4 damage to those rounds that hit.

Night Vision： Various vehicular night vision systems eliminate Dim and Dark @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.照明]{照明 } penalties as long as there is at least some amount of ambient light.

Reaction Fire: These weapons have special abilities in @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.追逐与载具]{追逐 }.

Sloped Armor: Sloped armor deflects shots away from the hull. Direct-fire ballistic attacks against the vehicle, such as a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.地面载具]{坦克 } gun or @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.火箭发射器与鱼雷表]{巴祖卡 }, suffer a −2 @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.射击]{射击 } penalty.

Spacecraft: The vehicle is designed for use in outer space. Those noted as Atmospheric can enter and exit planetary atmospheres as well.

Stabilizer: A stabilizer reduces the @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.不稳平台]{不稳平台 } penalty for whatever weapon it’s attached to (usually the main gun of a tank or armored vehicle). The penalty is reduced to −1 for a Stabilizer and 0 for an Improved Stabilizer.

Stealth Paint: Radar-absorbent black paint makes the vehicle less detectable by sensors. @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.电子学]{电子学 } rolls to spot or lock onto the target are made at −4.

Tracked: Tracked vehicles can climb over most low obstacles such as logs or low rocks, and can push through snow, mud, and other slippery surfaces. They ignore movement penalties for @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.移动]{困难地形 }.

Weapons: Vehicles with weapons note their location for narrative play and for the @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.追逐与载具]{追逐 } rules. Here are the most common：

  • FIXED: The vehicle’s weapon fires only in the listed direction (typically front or rear in a 45° arc).
  • PINTILE MOUNT: A raised swivel mount that can fire in a 180° arc to the listed direction. If mounted on the turret it must fire in the same facing as the turret each turn.
  • TURRET: The weapon is in a turret and has a 360° arc of fire.

Vehicles.name: 载具
Vehicles.description:
Vehicles

Sample lists of vehicles (@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.飞行器表]{飞行器 }、@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.地面载具]{地面载具 }和@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.船只表]{船只 }) are included in Chapter Two (Gear) along with any relevant @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.载具注释] .

Vehicular weapons work just like any other—characters make @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.射击]{射击 } rolls to hit a target and roll damage if successful (plus a bonus die if they hit with a raise). Unless a character has the @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-edges.手稳]{手稳 } Edge, don’t forget the @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.不稳平台]{不稳平台 } penalty.

Damage and how to handle vehicles on the tabletop are covered under @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.追逐与载具]{追逐与载具 }.

Vehicular Weapons Table.name: 载具武器表
Vehicular Weapons Table.description:
Vehicular Weapons

Below are the most common weapons mounted on military vehicles in the 20th century and beyond. All except the medium machine gun and Gatling laser are @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.重武器 (HW)]{重武器 }.

Minimum Rate of Fire: Vehicular weapons with a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.射速]{射速 } 3 or higher have a minimum Rate of Fire of 2.

Heavy Flamethrowers: Vehicular flamethrowers have longer ranges than personal devices. The wielder can use the Cone Template or arc a blast the size of a Medium Blast Template up to 18” (36 yards) distant. (Use the center of the template for the Range.) This shot can Deviate (see @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.范围效果攻击]{范围效果攻击 }).

Increase the weapon’s damage dice by one when fired at half their Short Range or less (so 4d10+2 becomes 5d10+2, for example).

Wild Attack.name: 不羁攻击
Wild Attack.description:
Wild Attack

Sometimes a desperate character may want to throw caution to the wind and attack with everything he’s got.

A Wild Attack adds +2 to the character’s @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.格斗]{格斗 } attacks and resulting damage rolls for the turn, but he is @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.分神与脆弱]{脆弱 } until the end of his next turn (not this one).

不羁攻击 can be used with multiple attacks, such as from @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.多重动作]{多重动作 } or the @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-edges.连击]{连击 } and @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-edges.横扫]{横扫 } Edges.

Wild Cards and Extras.name: 不羁角色与龙套们
Wild Cards and Extras.description:
Wild Cards & Extras

Your hero (a player character), and unique allies, villains, and monsters are collectively called “Wild Cards.” These beings have a better chance at doing things, are a little tougher to put down, and are generally more detailed than common guards, minions, or lackeys—collectively called “Extras.”

Wild Cards are noted with a design of some sort before their name, like this：

RED

The actual Wild Card symbol varies and is usually themed for the particular setting, such as a skull-and-crossbones for a pirate game like 50 Fathoms or a marshal’s badge in Deadlands.

Besides your own characters, it’s up to the Game Master to decide which characters are Wild Cards. The sergeant of the City Watch probably isn’t a Wild Card, but Sergeant Grimlock of the City Watch may be. Skytch the Dragon is also a Wild Card, though his three young wyrms aren’t.

Wild Cards are those who have stepped up to do more than most. They dare, aspire, and risk it all to be a hero—or a villain!

They have two special abilities in the game：

  • Wild Cards can take three @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.伤害效果]{损伤 } before they’re @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.伤害效果]{无力化 }.
  • Wild Cards roll a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性投骰]{不羁骰 }(usually a d6) along with their @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性]{特性 } die when making @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性投骰]{特性投骰 } and take the highest of the two as their total (see @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性投骰]{不羁骰 }).

Wound Cap.name: 损伤阈值
Wound Cap.description:
Wound Cap

Use this Setting Rule when you want combat to remain dangerous but reduce the chances of characters (and villains!) dying from a single lucky blow. It can still happen, but it is far more rare.

Characters can never suffer more than four @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.伤害效果]{损伤 } in a single hit and therefore never have to @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.化解投骰]{化解 } more than four wounds either!

Large Creatures： The Wound Cap applies even to creatures with more than three Wounds (due to their @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.体型与尺寸]{尺寸 } or the @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特殊能力 (强韧/非常强韧)]{Resilient/Very Resilient Special Ability }). A Huge creature that can take five Wounds, for example, can’t take more than four from a single attack, so it can’t normally be killed with a single attack. The GM can always overrule this in specific and obvious situations, of course, such as massive blasts, falling from towering cliffs or mountains, etc.

Wealth.name: 财富
Wealth.description:
Wealth

The fight against evil can sometimes be expensive! The system here makes managing money in the game a bit easier and occasion­ally dramatic.

When to Use These 规则： Use the Wealth system if you want a quick and easy way of handling financial resources without tracking actual currency.

The Basics： Characters have a new statistic called Wealth they can use to buy things. It increases when they’re rewarded and decreases after significant purchases.

Buying Things

Each character has a d6 in Wealth, which represents average, middle class resources for the setting. This isn’t a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性]{特性 }, but acts like one—players may spend @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.助力点]{助力点 } when checking it, get their @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性投骰]{不羁骰 }, and benefit from allies’ @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.援助]{援助 }.

When a hero wants to buy something mundane, she does so—no roll is required. If the item is more than about $10 × her Wealth die, or she’s made numerous recent trivial purchases, she must make a Wealth roll. The GM should add bonuses for savings or deals, subtract penalties for expensive purchases, or rule out all-together purchases beyond the character’s means.

@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性投骰]{大失败 } means the buyer can’t scrape up the needed funds at the moment but may try again the next week, or after he obtains one or more Rewards (see below). With a regular failure, the buyer can either forgo the expense or she can buy it but goes broke (defined below) regardless of her Wealth die.

Success means she purchases the item but her Wealth is reduced a die type until the GM feels her finances are restored by time or Rewards. A @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性投骰]{优良 } means she buys the item without reducing her Wealth.

Going Broke

If a hero’s Wealth would be reduced below d4, she’s dead broke. She has basic food, water, and shelter (unless the GM and the situation dictate otherwise), but otherwise can’t buy luxury foods, transportation, or even ammo.

Poor or Rich Characters

Wealth is only permanently increased by Rewards or the @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-edges.富裕]{富裕 } @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.专长]{专长 }. It’s decreased through use and the @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-hindrances.贫穷]{贫穷 } @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.负赘]{负赘 }. Those with the Poverty Hindrance have a d4 Wealth. Rich characters have a d8, and Very Rich heroes have a d10.

Heroes with the @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-edges.小有名气]{小有名气 } Edge add +1 to their Wealth rolls or +2 if they’re Famous. Not only do they tend to have more money, but people love to give discounts to celebrities.

Support Rolls

Other characters may @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.援助]{援助 } a hero’s Wealth roll, but assume the same risks as the buyer (losing a die type in Wealth with success, for example).

Availability

If an item isn’t commonly available, finding it on the black market, via a private dealer, or in an internet chat room requires the @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.调查]{调查 } skill or @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.打点关系]{打点关系 }.

The GM can also simply decide the item isn’t available or she can assign a modifier to the hero’s roll as she sees fit. Finding a firearm in modern-day Europe, for example, is at least a −4 penalty, with serious consequences if the roll is failed.

Rewards

Getting paid for a job or finding treasure increases the characters’ Wealth die one step for an average task, two for a particularly lucrative reward, or three for a very great reward.

Rewards and cost of living are relative, so the increase lasts only for a month of game time or until the GM thinks the party’s lifestyle, carousing, or general living expenses restores it to normal.

Negotiating

Players love to negotiate with those who hire them, but an increase in cash rarely means anything in actual gameplay. Using this system means a successful negotiation, as well as bounties and rewards, gives them a tangible bonus to their finances.

At least for a while!

Reload.name: 装填
Reload.description:
Reload

Reloading magazines, clips, and individual bullets in modern firearms is explained in detail in @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.装填]{装弹 }.

Some weapons, such as muskets and heavy crossbows, are much slower to reload. Once fired, the number after the word Reload is how many @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.动作]{动作 } of reloading it takes before they can be fired again.

Activation.name: 启动
Activation.description:
启动

角色可以通过选择@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.射程]{射程 }内的某一目标并进行一次@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.奥法背景]{奥法 }技能投骰来启动一个@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.奇术]{奇术 }。若投骰结果小于4则意味着奇术没能启动。除非能力有特别说明可以将最低费用减少到0，否则无论是否具有@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-edges.导能]{导能 }之类的@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.专长]{专长 }，施术者都要消耗1点@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.奥法背景]{奇术点 }。

投骰结果为4或更高意味着奇术成功启动，无论是没能命中目标(诸如矢箭)亦或防守方成功抵抗，所有分配的@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.奥法背景]{奇术点 }都会消耗殆尽。

成功意味着角色消耗了@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.奥法背景]{奇术点 }，并开始结算奇术效果。出现@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性投骰]{优良 }的额外效果会写在奇术的描述中。

反冲：启动奇术时出现的@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性投骰]{大失败 }称为反冲，这会造成一级@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.疲乏]{疲乏 }并终止所有当前激活的奇术。

团体投骰：当大群NPC被某一奇术影响时，GM可以选择进行@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性投骰]{团队投骰 }。举例而言，在受到@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.范围效果攻击]{范围效果攻击 }时，把相似目标划分为对应单组并分别进行伤害投骰十分有效，但对于尝试摆脱纠缠或类似奇术时需分开投骰。

施术需求

角色必须能看到目标且不处于@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.束缚与纠缠]{束缚 }。

维持奇术

消耗1点@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.奥法背景]{奇术点 }可以让奇术以基础@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.奇术]{持续时间 }为单位延长一次。举例而言，若奇术的持续时间是五@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.战斗]{轮 }，那么消耗1点奇术点可以再维持五轮。

维持奇术按目标数量计算，但忽略其他@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.奇术调整]{奇术调整 }，因此延长三名盟友身上的@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-powers.提升/降低特性]{提升特性 }消耗3点@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.奥法背景]{奇术点 }，每名对象的效果延长五轮。

除非奇术另有说明，否则施术者能以一个自由动作终止奇术。

充能

角色每进行1小时的休息或冥想之类就可以恢复5点@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.奥法背景]{奇术点 }。怎样算作“休息”由GM决定，但处于维持奇术、消耗一定体力，情绪受压、或是心神不宁的状态时无法充能。举例而言，角色可以骑马时休息，但马匹不能疲倦不安、道路不能异常颠簸、交通状况无须经常多加注意等等。

角色们同样可以在行走中恢复@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.奥法背景]{奇术点 }，不过需要状况大致理想，而且@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.移动]{移速 }也要休闲从容。

多重动作施放奇术

每个奇术启动时都会占用对应的@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.动作]{动作 }，而通过@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.多重动作]{多重动作 }可以多次施放同一或不同的奇术。举例而言，奇幻设定中的法师可以在开战时施放@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-powers.防护]{防护 }和@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-powers.偏斜]{偏斜 }，牧师也许会尝试@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-powers.放逐]{放逐 }幽魂的同时对@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-equipment.硬头锤]{硬头锤 }施放@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-powers.痛击]{痛击 }。

减耗

角色施放奇术时可以消耗低于需求的@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.奥法背景]{奇术点 }(无论奇术点够不够)，但这会增加@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.奥法背景]{奥法 }技能投骰的难度。

角色每减耗1点奇术点，投骰就会遭受-1减值。举例而言，将3奇术点的@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-powers.医疗]{治疗 }以0奇术点消耗施放，就会造成-3减值。

减耗有风险。若减耗时的奥法技能投骰失败，则会直接视为@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性投骰]{大失败 }！

Advancement.name: 升级
Advancement.description:
升级

角色扮演游戏其中一个最棒的部分就是角色升级，并见证这名人物从入门迈向传奇。

《狂野世界》中的升级取决于规划的战役长度。对于游戏次数不多于10回的短战役，推荐角色在每回游戏结束后升级。在单次超短团里面，甚至还能允许角色在该次冒险的中间升级(倘若其中具有合理的休整期或是叙事机会就更是如此)。

如果是长战役则也能放缓速度，每两回游戏给予升级，或者打算玩上几年，甚至可以每三回游戏给予升级。也可以在达到特定目的后再决定给予升级—􍄔这全在GM的掌控当中。

升级能让角色实现下列其中一项，记住任何@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性]{特性 }都不能升到超过种族上限(通常都是d12)。

  • 获得一项新@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.专长]{专长 }
  • 让某一大于等于其关联属性的@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性]{技能 }骰子类型增长一级。
  • 让两项骰子类型小于其关联属性的技能各自增长一级(包括角色之前没有的新技能，提升为d4)。
  • 让某一属性的骰子类型增长一级，该选项每个位阶(见下文的位阶)只能选一次。传奇角色每升两级能让某一属性增长一次，直到种族上限为止。
  • 永久移除某一次要@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.负赘]{负赘 }，或将某一主要负赘降为次要负赘(如有可能)。在得到GM的允许以及理由得当时，可以存满两次升级，并用来移除某一主要负赘。玩家和GM要一起敲定实现的时间和经过。也许是某一盟友的可怕死亡成为了角色改变态度的契机，让其开始真正付诸努力以改善不良行为，甚至会在任务中间的休整期寻求专业帮助。

位阶

角色升级时也会在“位阶”上有所提高，这是用以评估角色有多强大的粗略指标。每个位阶都能让角色得以选取更多的强力@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.专长]{专长 }和特定能力(比如@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.奇术]{奇术 })！

位阶
升级次数 位阶
0-3 入门
4-7 行家
8-11 老练
12-15 英杰
16+ 传奇

以有经验的角色开始游戏

如果GM想以更有经验的角色开始游戏，玩家也应该先建立一个入门角色，然后如常升级。这保证了角色的平衡性，如同其正常地经受历练。

额外的东西、装备或其他资产资产必须由GM以及对应设定来决定。以下是简化的快速规则：角色的起始资金在入门后每多出一个位阶就会翻倍。

更换角色：这里鼓励玩家在角色死亡时创建一名入门位阶的新人物，并给予其与先前陨落的人物同样数量的升级。

盟友与升级

随从和其他长时间留在团队里面的盟友也能提升自己的能力。

在每回游戏的末尾，在其中扮演重要角色的盟友(通常是参与战斗，但由GM判断)能如同玩家角色一样获得升级。

Allies.name: 盟友
Allies.description:
Allies

Allies play a big part in many Savage Worlds games. They serve as troops under your hero’s command in Weird Wars, loyal retainers in fantasy settings, or fellow fighters in glorious rebellions against oppression.

When to Use These 规则： Use these rules to help keep track of the party’s followers and give them a little extra personality to play off of as well.

The Basics: Players create, control, and track their own followers and nonplayer character allies.

Using Allies

Keeping up with allies in Savage Worlds is simple. Just download the Ally Sheet from our website and fill in the blanks.

Allied @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.不羁角色与龙套们]{龙套 } are divided up among all the players to control. This is a very important part of Savage Worlds because our settings often feature allied bands of skilled hirelings, fellow grunts, or loyal retainers, and the game is designed to handle them quickly and easily. It’s also designed for the players to control them—not the Game Master.

It doesn’t matter whether or not the characters control the allies, only that the players do. This keeps everyone involved in the action even if his hero is out of the fight, and makes running large combats much easier and more fun for everyone. Of course the GM can always take charge of Extras when the need arises, but with good roleplayers this should rarely be necessary.

Allied Personalities

You can add a little flavor to your allies by rolling on the Allied Personalities table. Jot down the keyword on the Ally Sheet so you and your Game Master have a little insight into each particular ally’s character.

Consider these general impressions with no particular game effect. They help both the player and GM decide just how an ally might react in a given situation. In a Weird War Two game, for instance, a player with a young lieutenant character could look over his list and choose the “Observant” character to pull guard duty. If he has to go with the “Lazy” soldier for some reason, there’s a good chance the GM will rule he falls asleep sometime during his watch.

Allied Personalities
D20 Personality D20 Personality
1 Treacherous 11 Crude
2 Cruel 12 Agile
3 Old 13 Observant
4 Happy 14 Clueless
5 Experienced 15 Mysterious
6 Gung-Ho 16 Creative
7 Lazy 17 Artistic
8 Sneaky 18 Fearless
9 Bright 19 Cowardly
10 Young 20 Heroic


Allies & Advancement

Allies can improve their abilities as well. See @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.升级]{升级 }.

@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.弹药表]{弹药 }

Keeping track of ammo for all your allies can be difficult. Here’s an easy and dramatic way to handle this problem.

The ammo level of each group of allied Extras starts at Very High, High (the usual level), Low, or Out, as determined by the GM.

After each fight, the ammo automatically drops a level. This makes for dramatic situations and realistic logistical problems while eliminating the bookkeeping.

The GM can always decide otherwise, of course. Perhaps the troops are told to fight with hand weapons instead of their firearms, or they don’t get to fire off more than a couple of shots before the fight is over.

Typical Allies

Here are a few typical soldier archetypes you might use for your Savage Worlds games. Fill in any additional Traits @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性]{技能 }或@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.专长]{专长 } as you see fit. A group of rangers, for example, should have the @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.生存]{生存 } skill, while cavalrymen should have the @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.骑乘]{骑乘 } skill, and so on.

Soldier

@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性]{属性 }: Agility d6, Smarts d4, Spirit d6, Strength d6, Vigor d6

@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性]{技能 }: @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.运动]{运动 } d6, @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.通用知识]{通用知识 } d6, @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.格斗]{格斗 } d6, @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.威吓]{威吓 } d6, @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.察觉]{察觉 } d6, @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.交涉]{交涉 } d6, @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.射击]{射击 } d6, @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.潜行]{潜行 } d4

@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.移动]{移速 }: 6; @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.角色]{格挡 }: 5; @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.角色]{坚韧 }: 5

@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.负赘]{负赘 }: —

@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.专长]{专长 }: @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-edges.士兵]{士兵 }

Experienced Soldier

@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性]{属性 }: Agility d6, Smarts d6, Spirit d6, Strength d8, Vigor d8

@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性]{技能 }: @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.运动]{运动 } d6, @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.通用知识]{通用知识 } d6, @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.格斗]{格斗 } d8, @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.威吓]{威吓 } d6, @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.察觉]{察觉 } d6, @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.交涉]{交涉 } d6, @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.射击]{射击 } d8, @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.潜行]{潜行 } d6

@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.移动]{移速 }: 6; @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.角色]{格挡 }: 6; @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.角色]{坚韧 }: 6

@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.负赘]{负赘 }: —

@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.专长]{专长 }: Soldier and any two combat Edges.

Interludes.name: 幕间
Interludes.description:
Interludes

Interludes are tales the players tell in-character to roleplay, enhance a long travel scene, or reveal the secrets and backstories they’ve put so much effort into.

When to Use These 规则： Interludes give players a way to get to know their characters, reveal some of their backstories, and even add to the world you’re all building together.

The Basics： Players tell a story from their character’s point of view and are rewarded with a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.助力点]{助力点 }.

Running An Interlude

When you want to give your players a moment to catch their breath and get into character, allow those who want to take part to draw a card from the @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.行动卡 (先攻)]{行动卡 }. The suit of the card gives each player three choices: Downtime, Backstory, or Trek. (If a player draws a Joker give everyone an extra @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.助力点]{助力点 } and let them choose the suit and category!)

  • DOWNTIME: What the hero does when left alone. A priest might quietly read a holy text while a warrior constantly sharpens his blades.
  • BACKSTORY: A tale of the character’s past, told through her voice and narration.
  • TREK: The story of an obstacle or challenge the party encountered on their trip.

Reward

Those players who participate in the ­Interlude receive a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.助力点]{助力点 }.

Interludes
Spades
Downtime: The character spends time alone in quiet contemplation. What does she do?
Backstory: A great victory or personal triumph.
Trek: A difficult obstacle the group negotiated along the way.
Hearts
Downtime: The hero practices a skill. What is it?
Backstory: A tale of the hero’s greatest love—lost, found, present, or waiting on her back home.
Trek: How the party endured a trying hardship on the journey.
Diamonds
Downtime: The character studies or works on an object of some sort. What is it?
Backstory: Something your hero wants or already has. It might be a material possession, recognition, a political goal, or even a trip he wishes to take to some amazing destination.
Trek: How the group found something that helped them along the way, such as an oasis, minor treasure, ammo, food, friendly locals, etc.
Clubs
Downtime: Your hero broods or is angry about something. What is it, and how does she misbehave?
Backstory: A tale of misfortune from your hero’s past, perhaps revealing something of his Hindrances or a dark secret.
Trek: A hardship the party overcame on their trip: the tragic death of a favored Extra, spoiled or lost supplies, a mechanical breakdown, abysmal weather, and so on.

Quick Encounters.name: 快速遭遇
Quick Encounters.description:
Quick Encounters

Sometimes the @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.主持游戏]{游戏主持人 } may want to quickly sum up an encounter rather than track every action round by round. “Quick Encounters” resolve these kinds of situations with good collaborative storytelling, tension, and risk.

When to Use These 规则： Use Quick Encount­ers when you’re pressed for time, the group isn’t as interested in tactical fights, or they do something the GM isn’t prepared for, like infiltrating a large complex she hasn’t detailed.

The Basics： Characters make a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性投骰]{技能投骰 } based on the type of encounter and their goal and interpret the results narratively with the Game Master.

Encounter Types

No @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.行动卡 (先攻)]{行动卡 } are dealt in a Quick Encounter. Instead, the GM describes the scene, then the players agree on a general plan and what each of their characters will do.

Once everyone states their intent, they can pick the skill that best represents their actions during the encounter.

Here are some examples：

  • CHASE: @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.通用知识]{通用知识 } (for navi­gation), @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.驾驶]{驾驶 }、@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.修理]{修理 }、@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.射击]{射击 }.
  • COMBAT: @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.格斗]{格斗 }、@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.射击]{射击 }、@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.奥法背景]{奥法技能 }.
  • CRISIS: @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.骇客]{骇客 }、@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.察觉]{察觉 }、@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.潜行]{潜行 }、@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.贼活]{贼活 }.
  • HEIST: @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.通用知识]{通用知识 } (for navi­gation), @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.驾驶]{驾驶 }、@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.修理]{修理 }、@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.射击]{射击 }.
  • MISSION: @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.作战]{作战 }、@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.驾船]{驾船 }、@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.格斗]{格斗 }、@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.交涉]{交涉 }、@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.航空]{航空 }、@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.射击]{射击 }.
  • TREK: @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.通用知识]{通用知识 }、@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.察觉]{察觉 }、@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.生存]{生存 }.

Modifiers： The GM should assign modifiers based on the situation. If the heroes greatly outnumber their opposition, pursue much slower prey, have prior experience with the obstacles in their path, or special equipment to deal with hazards, the roll might be made at +1 to +4.

Very difficult encounters, such as powerful foes (relative to the party), faster prey, or extreme conditions inflict a −1 to −4 penalty.

Turn Order & Critical Actions

Players can go in whatever order they want in a Quick Encounter. This might be important if some of their @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.动作]{动作 } are dependent on someone else’s. In a heist, for example, the group might depend on the hacker to shut down a company’s security measures before they can break in. Similarly, the crew of a B-17 in Weird War Two might need the navigator to get them to the mission location before they can fend off enemies and bomb a target.

Resolve these kinds of actions in the order that makes sense, and allow those who come after to change their own plans as the situation changes.

If a critical task is failed, the GM must decide if it stops the encounter or simply complicates it (perhaps inflicting a penalty to everyone else’s roll). In the heist example above, for example, maybe the hacker does break in but alerts the guards, inflicting a −2 penalty to Stealth or combat rolls and possibly turning the operation deadly. In the Weird War Two example, the navigator might still get them to the location but arrives just as the enemy fighters respond and make things more difficult.

These kinds of complications might also mean resolving the encounter in multiple stages instead of one roll as the heroes must react to the changing circumstances (see Staged Encounters, immediately below).

Staged Encounters

Quick Encounters are typically a single die roll followed by some narration between the GM and the players. But some encounters might need additional rounds to better reflect the results or any new information or events that come to light.

If the heist to break into a pawn shop and steal a powerful occult artifact goes badly, for example, the next stage might become a crisis when the shop suddenly bursts into supernatural flames. That might then lead to a combat encounter as an artifact in the shop breaks and releases an angry djinn!

The beauty of staged encounters is their ability to handle complex problems when the constraints of time or larger narrative require a speedy resolution.

Encounter Results

Once each player has determined her @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性]{技能 } and any @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.奇术调整]{调整值 }, she rolls the dice and works with the Game Master to narrate the details based on the total, the situation, and the other players’ actions.

Dangerous Encounters

If a character fails his roll in a dangerous situation he takes a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.伤害效果]{损伤 } (or d4 Wounds with a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性投骰]{大失败 }). If he’s the driver of a vehicle, it takes a Wound (or d4 with a Critical Failure). Wounds may be @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.化解投骰]{化解 } as usual.

Success means the hero emerges with only @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.肿痛与擦伤]{肿痛与擦伤 }, and a raise means he escapes unscathed.

Nonlethal Encounters

If the encounter isn’t physically dangerous, failure means the hero doesn’t contribute to the party’s overall success somehow. @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性投骰]{大失败 } means she suffers social stigma, loses or breaks a piece of vital equipment, is positively identified, or gets the wrong information. This likely means moving on to a second stage of the encounter as she deals with the fallout of her errors.

Success & Failure

In general, narration and individual actions determine the success or failure of an encounter. If the hacker can’t get past a building’s security measures, for example, and the GM decides it shuts down the operation rather than complicating it, the encounter fails. In other words, let the story tell the tale.

In a more dynamic situation such as @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.战斗]{战斗 }, assume the group “wins” if there are at least as many total successes (one for each success and raise) as there are player characters. They get the information, drive off their foes, complete the mission, or avert (or escape) the crisis. @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.援助]{援助 } rolls don’t count as successes.

If there are fewer successes than player characters, they fail. Specifics are up to the Game Master, but might mean the party has to fall back or retreat from their foes, their prey escapes, they don’t get the object or data they were looking for, they survive the crisis but can’t save most of the bystanders, and so on.

If they can try again, the GM should “reset” the encounter with the new narrative so the group has to come up with a new plan. And of course, their foes are likely on to them now!

Ammo & Power Points

Use the rules for@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.弹药表]{弹药 } &@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.奥法背景]{获得奇术点 } under @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.大规模作战]{大规模作战 } for combat encounters if desired. Otherwise the player and GM can just decide what resources were consumed in the encounter.

Example: Night At The Museum

Red and Gabe must break into a museum, steal an ancient book, and stop a global conspiracy that threatens all of humanity.

The group decides to play out the break-in as a Quick Encounter. Red plans to use @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.贼活]{贼活 } to break into the museum, take the manuscript, then escape out the back. Gabe will @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.援助]{援助 } her using @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.骇客]{骇客 } as she runs into trouble.

The GM decides Red’s Thievery roll is at −2 to get into the museum. Gabe tries to turn off cameras and unlock security doors as she goes, Supporting her Thievery roll with Hacking. He gets one success and adds +1 to his friend’s roll.

Red manages a single success, but since there are two player characters and the rules say they need at least as many successes as there are characters, they fail.

The GM says several night watchmen are alerted by the pair’s actions and begin prowling through the museum. Red and Gabe can continue if they want, but the encounter is now more difficult (−2). The GM also says it’s now “dangerous” as the guards are armed and nervous.

With the fate of the world at stake, the heroes agree to press on. Red now uses @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.潜行]{潜行 } to avoid the guards. Gabe gives up on Hacking, borrows some clothing from a passing tourist, and knocks on the door, pretending to be lost! The GM tells him to use @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.表演]{表演 } and he rolls a 21! Both characters are successful, so the ancient manuscript is secured!

Special Ability (Wall Walker).name: 特殊能力 (走壁)
Special Ability (Wall Walker).description:
Wall Walker

Some creatures have the ability to walk on walls. They automatically walk on vertical or inverted surfaces just as a human walks on the earth.

A Wall Walker’s movement rate when walking on walls is its standard @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.移动]{移速 }. It may run as usual when walking on walls unless the specific creature’s text says otherwise.

Support.name: 援助
Support.description:
Support

Sometimes characters may want to cooperate or help an ally with a task. If so, and the GM decides it’s possible, supporting characters roll the relevant @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性]{技能 } (on their action if the game is in rounds) and declare which of their ally’s skills they’re attempting to Support.

Success grants the ally +1 to one  @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性]{技能 } total this round, and a raise adds +2. A Critical Failure on the support roll subtracts 2 from the lead’s total—sometimes extra hands just get in the way!

Remove all Support bonuses at the end of the recipient’s turn, whether he used them or not (perhaps by taking an action different than the one he was Supported for).

The maximum bonus from all Support rolls is +4. @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性]{力量 } checks are an exception and have no maximum bonus since more muscle can always manage more mass.

Players and GMs should be creative when making Support rolls. An adventurer with @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.生存]{生存 }, for example, might make a roll to find useful herbs for an ally attempting a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-powers.医疗]{医疗 } check, or a galactic explorer with @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.科学]{科学 } might calculate slingshot vectors that help a friend make a tricky @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.航空]{航空 } roll.

General encouragement (a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.交涉]{交涉 } roll) such as “You can do it!” or “Check your six!” are perfectly acceptable, but at the GM’s discretion lose effectiveness if repeated.

Example: Gabe is the driver in a chase. Red points out a shortcut by yelling, “Take the next left!” She rolls @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.通用知识]{通用知识 } and gets a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性投骰]{优良 }. Gabe adds +2 to his next @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.驾驶]{驾驶 } roll. Later on, Red is hit by a ricochet and is @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.伤害效果]{动摇 }. Gabe yells, “Toughen up, cowgirl! This ain’t your first rodeo!” and makes a Persuasion roll. He gets a success and Red adds +1 to her upcoming Spirit total to recover from being @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.伤害效果]{动摇 }.

Support vs. @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.考验]{考验 }

The Support option can be used against an opponent narratively, but the only effect it can have is as detailed above. If a character wants to “trip up” an ogre to help a friend make a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.格斗]{格斗 } roll against it, for example, she can add +1 or +2 to his roll, but she doesn’t actually trip the ogre. It’s not made @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.卧地]{卧地 }、@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.分神与脆弱]{分神 }、@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.分神与脆弱]{脆弱 }或是@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.伤害效果]{动摇 } as it might if she had used the @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.考验]{考验 } option.

The advantage for a player in making a Support roll over a @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.考验]{考验 } is to help an ally and avoid a more difficult @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性投骰]{对抗投骰 } for the @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.考验]{考验 } (even though narratively it might seem like it should be an @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.特性投骰]{对抗投骰 }).

Withdrawing From Melee.name: 撤出近战
Withdrawing From Melee.description:
Withdrawing From Melee

Whenever a character retreats from melee, all adjacent non-@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.伤害效果]{动摇 } and non-@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.震慑]{震慑 } opponents get an immediate Free Attack (see @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.自由攻击]{自由攻击 }).

Example： Red is surrounded by five strange xenos and must get to a wounded Gabe. She takes the @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.防御]{防御 } option (increasing her @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.角色]{格挡 } by +4) and backs away. All five xenos get a Free Attack, at +4 for @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.围攻]{围攻 }. Fortunately, Red’s high @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-rules.角色]{格挡 } fends them off and she makes her way to her injured friend.
